content.headline: When Good Design Decisions Go Bad
The Planes That Never Came Back
During World War II, the U.S. military studied returning bombers to decide where to add armor.
content.body:
Analysts carefully mapped bullet holes on the planes that made it home. The data looked clear.

Reinforce the most damaged areas.

content.headline: "You're looking at the wrong planes."
content.body: The holes you see are where a plane can get shot and survive. You should be worried about the ones that didn't return.

content.headline: Visible success is biased data
takeaways: What survives is not what's most resilient — it's what didn't fail yet
Optimizing for what looks good reinforces the wrong thing
You end up strengthening the least critical parts of the system
content.body: Your happy-path demo is the plane that returned. The real product lives in failed setups, abandoned workflows, permission errors, rollback paths, and 2am incidents.

content.headline: A drunk searches for lost keys under a streetlight
content.body:
Not because that's where he dropped them, but because that's where the light is.

We collect data that is easy to collect.
content.source: Kaplan, A. (1964). The Conduct of Inquiry.

content.headline: We confuse visibility with importance
content.body:
What's missing: Data that is hard, expensive, or uncomfortable to obtain.

The most critical insights often live in the shadows.

content.headline: Measure what matters, not what's easy
takeaways: Analytics show clicks and flows, not confusion
Workarounds leave no trace in your dashboards
Shadow IT usage is invisible by design
content.body: Your analytics dashboard is the streetlight. The real UX problems are in the dark.

content.headline: Organizations design systems that mirror their communication structures
content.body: If you have four teams building a compiler, you'll get a four-pass compiler. The structure of your software reflects the structure of your org chart.
content.source: Conway, M. (1968). How Do Committees Invent?

content.headline: "Architecture is frozen politics"
content.body:
What's missing: The org charts, incentives, and power structures that shaped the design.

Inconsistent UX isn't a design failure — it's an organizational symptom.

content.headline: Design systems can't fix org dysfunction
takeaways: Fragmented UX often reflects team boundaries, not user needs
Siloed teams produce siloed experiences
If you want unified UX, you need unified teams
content.body: That inconsistent navigation bar? It's not a CSS problem. It's two teams who don't talk to each other.

stories.title: The Map Is Not the Territory

content.headline: Models simplify reality — but are often mistaken for reality itself
content.body:
Your user journey map shows a clean path. The reality includes forgotten passwords, permission errors, SSO redirects, and a dozen workarounds.

Diagrams, flows, and dashboards hide what actually happens.

content.headline: "The map is not the territory"
content.body:
What's missing: Messy real-world behavior, exception paths, edge cases, and human improvisation.

Your perfectly documented workflow is fiction.

content.headline: Test the territory, not the map
takeaways: User journeys hide exception paths that dominate real usage
Observational research beats user journey diagrams
If it's not in production logs, it's not real
content.body: That seamless onboarding flow in your deck? Watch 5 real users try it. The territory will surprise you.

content.headline: British colonial India offered a bounty for dead cobras to reduce the population
content.body:
Enterprising individuals began breeding cobras for income. When the program ended, breeders released their cobras—making the original problem worse.

Incentives don't just change behavior. They change entire systems.

content.headline: "Incentives change systems, not just behavior"
content.body:
What's missing: Second-order effects, gaming, and unintended consequences.

People optimize for the metric, not the outcome.

content.headline: Mandates create checkbox behavior
takeaways: Forcing usage through mandates creates compliance, not engagement
Users will game any system with perverse incentives
Measure outcomes, not activities
content.body: That mandatory UX training? People are passing the quiz without watching the videos. You incentivized completion, not learning.

content.headline: The Real Impact Shows Up Later
The real impact shows up later, elsewhere
content.body:
That quick UX patch shipped in two days? Six months later it's spawned workarounds, breaking changes, and a support backlog.

We see immediate improvements. We miss downstream complexity.

content.headline: "Short-term wins create long-term debt"
content.body:
What's missing: Downstream complexity, maintenance burden, and cascading failures.

The crisis arrives on a schedule you didn't plan for.

content.headline: Always ask: 'Then what?'
takeaways: Quick UX patches increase long-term operational cost
Every workaround is a time bomb set to 'later'
The real design question is 'What happens in 6 months?'
content.body: That temporary modal you added? It's been there for 3 years. Users built workflows around it. Now you can't remove it.

content.headline: A product worked flawlessly for small teams. Then a large customer onboarded.
content.body:
Lists became unbounded. Search became slow. Permissions became complicated. The same UI started producing outages and user errors.

The design wasn't wrong — it was unscaled.
content.source: The 13 Costly Mistakes in Enterprise Product Design [Part-1] (May 26, 2023)

content.headline: "Most enterprise UX breaks aren't at launch — they break at scale"
content.body:
What's missing: Performance budgets, virtualization, bulk operations, and progressive disclosure.

At scale, slow = confusing = risky. Time becomes the interface.

content.headline: Design for growth or design for rework
takeaways: Scalability is a UX requirement: pagination, virtualization, bulk actions
Test with realistic data volumes in your prototypes
Performance budgets matter — slow is broken UX
content.body: Empty states become pagination storms. Filters become mandatory. Tables become unusable. Bake in scale from day one.

content.headline: We assume others think like us
content.body:
Your internal team loves the new design. Everyone agrees it's intuitive. You ship it.

Real users are confused. The workflows don't match their mental models. Support tickets flood in.
content.source: Ross et al. (1977). False Consensus Effect

content.headline: "Consensus ≠ correctness"
content.body:
What's missing: User disagreement, different mental models, and external reality.

Internal dogfooding creates an echo chamber.

content.headline: Test with strangers, not teammates
takeaways: Internal dogfooding hides real usability gaps
Your team knows too much — they can't think like beginners
Watch users who've never seen your product before
content.body: That feature everyone on the team loves? Watch a customer use it for the first time. The bubble will burst.

content.headline: Extreme outcomes tend to normalize naturally
content.body:
Metrics crash. You panic, redesign the flow, and ship the fix. Two weeks later, metrics recover.

You credit the redesign. But the data was just returning to normal — it would have happened anyway.

content.headline: "Not every improvement is caused by the redesign"
content.body:
What's missing: Random variation, natural cycles, and baseline trends.

We attribute to intervention what was statistical normalization.

content.headline: Wait for the counterfactual
takeaways: Extreme metrics naturally regress — don't panic and redesign
Run A/B tests to separate signal from noise
Compare against a control group, not against the crisis
content.body: Conversion dropped 40%? Wait. Check for external factors. Don't ship a 'fix' until you know what actually broke.

content.headline: Most users only use the simplest part of any system
content.body:
Login? 95% usage. Advanced filters? 12%. Admin settings? 2%.

The power law is brutal: complexity kills adoption. Every advanced feature you build serves fewer users.

content.headline: "Complexity tax is real"
content.body:
What's missing: Drop-off rates, feature avoidance, and non-usage data.

Admin-heavy tools fail when basic tasks aren't effortless.

content.headline: Optimize the common path, not the edge case
takeaways: Track usage by feature — you'll be horrified
Make the top 3 tasks ridiculously easy
Advanced features can require more effort if basics are effortless
content.body: Your product has 50 features. Users use 5. If those 5 aren't perfect, the other 45 don't matter.

content.headline: The UI That Looked Correct — and Was Conceptually Wrong
A design team shipped flows that looked clean but didn't match how the industry actually thinks
content.body:
Terminology was off. Workflows skipped mandatory steps. Roles were misunderstood. The product didn't fail because the UI was ugly — it failed because it didn't reflect the domain's mental model.

If you don't speak the domain, you're designing a translation error.
content.source: More Costly Mistakes in Enterprise Product Design [Part-2] (May 26, 2023)

content.headline: "Domain knowledge is the backbone of enterprise UX"
content.body:
What's missing: Industry taxonomy, mandatory compliance steps, and user mental models.

Without domain depth, you optimize the wrong thing — and make confident mistakes.

content.headline: Learn the language before designing the interface
takeaways: Shadow real users doing real work — don't design from imagination
Build a shared terminology glossary with SMEs and engineering
Great enterprise UX feels 'obvious' only because it matches the user's conceptual model
content.body: You called it 'Submit.' They call it 'File a claim.' That gap is why your clean UI confuses everyone.

content.headline: Each team optimizes its part, but the system gets worse overall
content.body:
Onboarding: 95% completion. Dashboard: Fast load. Checkout: 88% conversion. Every screen optimized.

End-to-end workflow completion? 32%. Data doesn't transfer. Patterns clash. Users re-enter info.

content.headline: "Optimizing parts can harm the whole"
content.body:
What's missing: Cross-team coordination, end-to-end user journeys, and system-level metrics.

Great individual screens don't guarantee a usable workflow.

content.headline: Measure the end-to-end experience
takeaways: Track completion rates for full user journeys, not just individual screens
Assign owners to cross-team workflows
Local metrics can look great while the system fails
content.body: Your login is perfect. Your dashboard is fast. Your checkout converts. So why did users abandon mid-flow?

content.headline: A design was presented. PM agreed. Engineering agreed. No objections. No questions. It shipped.
content.body:
Three months later, users asked: 'Why does it work this way?'

No one remembered why.

Silence feels like alignment — until reality disagrees.

content.headline: "Agreement is not validation"
content.body:
What's missing: Critical questions, edge cases, and 'what breaks?' conversations.

Unchallenged assumptions are the most expensive ones.

content.headline: Invite dissent before you ship
takeaways: If nobody asks 'what breaks?', something will
Silent nods don't mean people understand — they mean they're being polite
Schedule 'red team' reviews where the goal is to find problems
content.body: That meeting where everyone agreed? That's when you're in the most danger.

content.headline: A team spent weeks aligning spacing, typography, tokens. Everything was consistent. Everything looked right.
content.body:
Users still couldn't complete their task without docs.

Consistency amplifies bad decisions.

content.headline: "Consistency is a multiplier, not a goal"
content.body:
What's missing: Workflow validation, user testing, and systems thinking.

A broken workflow repeated perfectly is still broken.

content.headline: Systems thinking beats component thinking
takeaways: Perfect tokens won't fix a confusing information architecture
Consistency makes good patterns better and bad patterns worse
Test the workflow, not just the components
content.body: Your design system is flawless. Your spacing is perfect. So why do users still need a 20-page guide?

stories.title: The PM Said It Was Fine

content.headline: A designer noticed an edge case. It felt odd. PM said: 'Let's ship — we'll fix later.'
content.body:
Later never came.

The edge case became the common case.

Delegated thinking is still your responsibility.

content.headline: "Ownership doesn't end at approval"
content.body:
What's missing: Designer accountability, speaking up, and owning the warning.

PM approval doesn't absolve design accountability.

content.headline: If you can see the crack, you own the warning
takeaways: Document your concerns in writing before shipping
PM approval is a business decision, not a design validation
Your job isn't just to deliver — it's to warn
content.body: You saw the crack. You stayed quiet. PM approval doesn't make it disappear.

stories.title: The Design That Worked in Figma

content.headline: The prototype was flawless. Transitions were smooth. Everything made sense.
content.body:
In production: APIs failed, data loaded slowly, states overlapped.

The design never considered partial failure.

Figma has no latency.

content.headline: "Real systems are hostile"
content.body:
What's missing: Loading states, error states, empty states, and partial failure handling.

If you didn't design loading, error, and empty states — you designed fiction.

content.headline: Production behavior is part of UX
takeaways: Design the loading state first, not last
Error states aren't edge cases — they're Tuesday
Test your design with throttled network and API failures
content.body: Your prototype is perfect. Your production experience crashes when the API is slow. Which one matters?

content.headline: The Planes That Never Came Back
Enterprise Translation
content.body: Content to be added

content.headline: Take Home
content.body: Content to be added
